awd_titl_txt: Conference: Hot Quarks 2022 A Workshop on the Physics of Ultrarelativistic Nucleus-Nucleus Collisions for Young Scientists
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides support for junior researchers to participate in the Hot Quarks Workshop to be held in Estes Park, Colorado, in October, 2022.  The main goal of the workshop is to educate and enhance collaboration among early career scientists in the quickly evolving field of “hot QCD”, more specifically QCD thermodynamics, hydrodynamics, non-equilibrium transport theory, and applications of AdS/CFT in heavy-ion collisions.  The workshop will provide an informal environment for junior researchers to interact, exchange ideas, and form a community of researchers.  Involving junior researchers in this workshop will provide an opportunity for them to learn about fundamental nuclear physics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant provided partial support for early career researchers to participate in the 9th Workshop for Early Career Heavy-Ion Physicists, Hot Quarks 2022, in Estes Park, Colorado on October 11-17, 2022. The Hot Quarks Workshop series is designed to train and foster collaboration among early career scientists researching physics related to relativistic heavy ion collisions. These collisions produce a unique state of matter that existed immediately following the Big Bang known as the quark gluon plasma (QGP) which allows us to study interactions between quarks and gluons that form protons and all visible matter.  Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) is the theory that describes the nuclear strong force and governs the interactions between quarks and gluons.  Advances of the theoretical models which describe the physics of the QGP were presented and discussed at the conference in addition to the latest results from recent experiments. Results from and upgrades to experiments at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) at Brookhaven National Lab and the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN were presented as well as plans for future facilities including the Electron Ion Collider.

Participants of the conference include graduate students and post-doctoral researchers who were selected to present their work based on their submitted abstract and invited speakers for overview talks who are experienced post-doctoral researchers or newly hired faculty. In addition to presentations on recent results, time alloted at the end of each session allowed for deeper discussions of the topics and provide answers to participant questions.  Topics covered included dynamics from the initial stages of the collisions, how probes interact with the QGP, hydrodynamic models of the observed flow, extraction of properties such as temperature and density, particle production and developments toward future experimental facilities. This conference successfully fostered discussion among participants which may lead to future collaborations and helped train a diverse group of early career researchers on the current status of the field of high energy nuclear collisions physics.
